newsitem.title: UK: U.S. Treasuries gain in London, demand steady.
newsitem.headline: U.S. Treasuries gain in London, demand steady.

text.p: U.S. Treasuries were stronger in London on Monday as steady demand supported the market, leaving it set to build-on recent gains, traders said.
Analysts said the main focus was on supply, with the U.S. auctioning shorter-dated paper at the start of the week.
"It's looking well bid out there, going into this auction," said a trader at a U.S. bank in London. "I can't see much that will shake that."
The U.S. 30-year long bond was at 100-20 by 1020 GMT, yielding 6.451 percent, compared with 100-19 in Tokyo and 100-16 at the New York close.
December T-bond futures were unchanged at 114-30 in automated trade.
Traders said losses on the long-bond on Friday were not indicative of the general tone in the market, and were a reflection of profit-taking ahead of the weekend.
"Demand is still good," said the U.S. trader. "The long-end was just a bit sluggish on Friday."

The U.S. Treasury was expected to auction $28.0 billion of three- and six-month paper later in Monday's session, followed by $18.25 billion of two-year notes on Tuesday and $12.5 billion of five-year notes on Wednesday.

Analysts said concerns surrounding the Federal Open Market Committee meeting last week had overshadowed previous auctions. With that threat removed, the path was clear for strong demand for the paper.
"The twos will be reasonably well-bid," said Peter Frank, senior economist at Sumitomo Finance in London. "There's nothing dramatic coming to disturb the positive tone."
He said he expected the bullish momentum in the market to continue in the short-term.
December T-bonds set a high of 115-15 on Friday, the highest level since late February.
